refnamediv.refpurpose: A filter with pronounced resonance and controllable decay time.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Filters the incoming signal with the specified resonance frequency and decay time. This can be used to overlay a specific resonance on to an incoming sound or to model short bursts of sinusoids at a desired frequency. With a sufficiently long decay time it can be used as a sinusoidal oscillator.

refsect1.title: Syntax
refsect1.synopsis: aout mvmfilter ain, xfreq, xTau [, iskip]

refsect1.title: Initialization
refsect1.para: iskip (optional, default=0) -- if non zero skip the initialisation of the filter.

refsect1.title: Performance
refsect1.para:
xfreq -- resonant frequency of the filter
Warning
The filter output can rapidly grow to very large output if the input signal correlates with the output. The worst case is that it grows by the magnitude of the input with every sample. To limit the growth so the filter doesn't explode, it's best to scale down any continuous input significantly.
The required scale is related to the value of the decay-time tau so if you select a maximum decay-time you can calculate the required scaling: factor = 1 / $M_E / (sr*tau)
xTau -- Decay time of the filter in seconds
The decay time is the time in seconds for filter to decay to 1/e

refsect1.title: References
refsect1.para: This filter is based on the work of Max Mathews and Julius O. Smith III. This filter was originally used by Max Mathews in an application which applied a bank of these filters to an incoming sound with live controls over the decay time and frequency parameters. This setup was the basis for collaborative live performance and was referred to as Phasor Filters.
